answers.answer: If doctor has advised you to monitor then may be he feels that problem is not severe and will subside.They will do a nerve conduction test , blood test to rule out diabetes  or a doppler scan.Don't worry and monitor the symptoms as advised by a doctor

question: Hi, I'm a 35 year old female.  I'm very physically active - play tennis, spin, yoga, jog.  Recently I noticed a few symptoms: Crossing my legs can cause my leg to start to fall asleep/tingling.  Also, certain positions (such as yoga or just typing at computer) will cause tingling in my fingers.  Once the position is changed the tingling goes away....but what concerns me is the frequency of these occurances which happen at least a few times throught the day within the past week or so.  I do have some back/shoulder/neck discomfort (due to lifting a 1-year old) but cannot really call it back pain. My primary care physician is not very much concerned, thinks it may be a pinched nerve, and I am just to monitor for the next week or so.  My question: is monitoring for the next week enough or do these symptoms call for testing now?  What tests sound appropriate?  Thank you.
title: Tingling in fingers & foot falls asleep
